turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You work those kind of hours, you got to have rest. Which you can't get with somebody jabbering away on a direct line to heaven.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Major Burns will be out of your tent in twenty-four hours.  Tell them Captain Pierce and Captain Forrest are on their way.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: About that chest-cutter...

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I'll try, d-d-dammit! You can't ask any more than that!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We don't want any more than that.  Right now.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Stop acting like a colonel, Henry. You know Trapper wouldn't sock him without a good reason.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: There's no reason good enough for one medical officer to strike another.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I should fire him because he got in the way of Trapper's fist? No. I've put up with a lot from you guys, but now I finally have to take disciplinary action.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Christ. All of a sudden it's West Point.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: First decent idea you've had in a month.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Now I'll have to wait at least a week. If I announced it tomorrow, after what our new Chief Nurse saw this afternoon, they'd hear her yelling from Seoul to Washington.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Fifteenth straight day there've been six o'clock choppers. How long can a battle go on?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You got to relax, Henry. Since the deluge started, you been working in the OR and running the outfit, too.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: It's a nice idea. I mean it has style.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: It's the only way we can make enough to put Ho-Jon through Androscoggin.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: What's going on? Who started this?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: You mean who hit who?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Yes, that's what I mean.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: I did. First and only blow. So far.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: If you say so, Henry. But remember my claustrophobia.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I deeply regret this unfortunate incident. We try to remember we're a military organization.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: What's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: I don't know. I must have lost my punch. I didn't think the son-of-a- bitch would get up.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: We got it, men... Ho-Jon's keep as Androscoggin... if there is such a place. And the big news is, the General wants a rematch.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: I'll tell you my news. I'm retiring from football.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: O'Reilly!

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Yes, sir?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Dammit, Radar, wait till I call you! Tell Major Burns...

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: One of the surgeons from the day shift will have to stay on duty tonight?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Yes, dammit, and...

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: O'Reilly, what is it?  There aren't more choppers coming?

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: I'm afraid so, Colonel.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: We've got too many wounded for us to handle now! Get on the phone right away and...

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Yes, sir, I'll see if I can reach General Hammond in Seoul for you. You think he'll finally break down and give us two more surgeons?

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Don't do that, Radar! You make me nervous.

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Don't come so quickly when I call. I want you to take these officers...

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: To Major Burns' tent. Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Stop that, O'Rielly!

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Oh, get out of here!

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Yes, Colonel.

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Good morning, Colonel.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Morning, Radar. How were things?

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Splendid, sir. No problems.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Morning, Captain.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Can you make out what they're talking about?

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: I can try, sir.

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: Chopper coming in, Colonel. Two of them, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: RADAR
turns.text: And another one, but it's from the south.  There.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: If I can make a suggestion, Coach.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: The way I run an organization, any man in it has the right to speak his mind.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: In that case, here are ten basic plays. I think that's about all this bunch can handle.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Thank you, Spearchucker. I'll certainly take a look at these. Where the hell did you ever get that name?

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: I used to throw the javelin.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: Those two big guys were tackles on the Cleveland Browns, and the redhead played halfback with the Rams.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: They can't do that to me!

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Well, there's one big satisfaction.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: What's that, Henry?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I out-coached that General Hammond.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Morning, girls. Good morning Major.

turns.speaker: HOT LIPS
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: This one goes right to the OR. Tell Duke to do him ahead of the busted spleen.  And this kid can't wait. I'll take him myself, before I get to that ruptured diaphragm.

turns.speaker: HOT LIPS
turns.text: Captain...  'This kid' is a prisoner of war.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: HOT LIPS
turns.text: It's an American boy's rupture you're supposed to close.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Listen, we get a deluge like this, just deciding priorities on a medical basis is hard enough. So never mind the side issues.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Okay, I'm closing up. Everybody relax.

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: May I have the surgeon's name, please?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Planes mostly. May take a crack at rickshaws. How does the direct approach work over here?

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: I been out of action since I got over here five months ago.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: What's the bastard really like?

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: Colonel Merrill is a veteran of twenty- five years in the Regular Army, a soldier first and a doctor second. A member of several patriotic organizations, he believes it's America's God-given mission to maintain a foothold for freedom on the Asian mainland.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: That bad?  But I guess you're right. We might as well see him.  Got any caddie carts?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Never mind.

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: The address of the N.E.P.H. and W. Why don't you meet me there when you're through golf for drinks and dinner and whatever strikes the fancy?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Mine's already been struck, and it doesn't have to be very fancy.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Soup? Rice? What are we doing, beginning all over again?

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: No, we had a clear soup to start. This is a thick one and you ought to taste it. There's nothing like it back home.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: How can I taste it now? We've already had like twelve courses.

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: Can you guys take one minute to look at a kid for me?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: We don't have to see him. Call that halfassed Army hospital and tell them to be ready to put some lipiodol in this kid's esophagus and take X- rays.

turns.speaker: ME LAY
turns.text: But it's ten-thirty at night. We can't get military personnel out for a civilian. A foreign civilian.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: How is he?

turns.speaker: UGLY JOHN
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Arterial silk.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Ease off on those tapes, and let's see how much it bleeds.  How is he?

turns.speaker: UGLY JOHN
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Boys, we're home free.

turns.speaker: UGLY JOHN
turns.text: As long as there's a pile-up, we can do our bit to encourage his permanent withdrawal from the contest.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: It's a technique Ugly John and I worked out in case something like this came up.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're a couple o' sticks shy in your column, Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A big, rich slob like D. B. Norton buys a paperand forty heads are chopped off!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Did you get it, too?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah. You, too? Oh, Joe . . . oh, I'm sorry darling . . . why don't we tear the building down!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Before you do, Ann, perhaps you'd better finish this column.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah. Lavender and old lace!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Er, would you, er, would you like to make some money?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, maybe.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Would you be willing to say you wrote that letterand stick by it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, I get the idea. Yeah, maybe.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, I'm all right.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Don't mind the Colonel. He hates people.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He likes you well enough to stick around.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, that's 'cause we both play doohickies. I met him in a box car a couple o' years ago. I was foolin' around with my harmonica and he comes over and joins in. I haven't been able to shake him since.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Action?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Um-hum.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Here. Sit down!  Quiet, egghead!  All right, now, a serious expression.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Can't. I'm feeling too good.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, come on, now. This is serious. You're a man disgusted with all of civilization.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: With all of it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, you're sore at the world. Come on, now.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, crabby guy, huh?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah. No, no!  No! No, look. You don't have to smell the world!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, all those guys in the bleachers think

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Never mind those guys. All right, stand up. Now let's see what you look like when you protest.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Against what?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Against anything. Just protest.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You got me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, look. I'm the umpire, and you just cut the heart of the plate with your fast one and I call it a ball. What would you do?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, yuh did, huh?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Why can't you call right, you bone- headed, pig-eared, lop-eared, pot- bellied

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Grab it, Eddie, grab it!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Now, look, John. Here's the speech. It's in caps and double-spaced. You won't have any trouble reading it. Not nervous, are you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Of course not. He wouldn't be.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John Doe. The one in there.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John Doe, the one in the speech.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh. Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You know something? I've actually fallen in love with him.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Say, he's a friend of mine.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Never mind. Let him alone. He's all right. I'll be right over there pulling for you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Hello, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Look, John. Something terribly important's happened. They're forming John Doe Clubs. We know of eight already and they say that there's going

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: John Doe Clubs? What for?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Uh-huh. To carry out the principles you talked about in your radio speech.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't care what they're forming. I'm on my way and I don't like the idea of being stopped either.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, but you don't know how big this thing is. You should see the thousands of telegrams we've received and what they're saying about you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, it started as a circulation stunt, didn't it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Uh-huh . . .

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, you got your circulation. Now, why don't you let me alone?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, it started as a circulation stunt, but it isn't any more. Mr. Norton wants to get back of it and sponsor John Doe Clubs all over the country. He wants to send you on a lecture tour.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Can I help you pack?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Do you care if I sit down out here?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You know, I had a crazy dream last night. It was about you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: About me?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sure was crazy. I dreamt I was your father.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, would you like to know who it was you were marrying?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, a tall handsome Ubangi, I suppose.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, not that bad. It was a fella that sends you flowers every day. Er, what's his name? Mr. Norton's nephew.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Ted Sheldon.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, that's the one.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: But here's the funniest part of it all. I was the fella up there doing the marrying. You know, the Justice of the Peace or something . . .

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You were? I thought you were chasing me?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, yes, I was. But I was your father then, see?  But the real me, John Doe, er, that is, Long John Willoughby, I was the fellow up there with the book. You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I guess so. Then what happened?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, I took you across my knee and I started spanking you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How many people do you think we've talked to already, outside the radio, I mean?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know. About three hundred thousand.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Three hundred thousand? What makes them do it, Ann? What makes them come and listen and, and get up their John Doe Clubs the way they do? I've been trying to figure it out.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Look, Johnwhat we're handing them are platitudes. Things they've heard a million times: "Love thy neighbor," "Clouds have silver linings," "Turn the other cheek." It's just a

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, I've heard them a million times, too, butthere you are. Maybe they're like me. Just beginning to get an idea what those things mean.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Did you write this?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, I did, John. But II had no idea what was going on.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You didn't?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Go ahead, driver! Ball park!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John, please let me go with you! Please, John!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: . . . Er, this John Doe idea is yours, huh?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: How much money do you get?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Thirty dollars.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Thirty dollars? Well, er, what are you after? I mean, what do you want? A journalistic career?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Money.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Money?  Well, I'm glad to hear somebody admit it. Do you suppose you could write a radio speech that would put that fellow over?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, I'm sure I can.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Do it, and I'll give you a hundred dollars a week.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A hundred dollars!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: That's only the beginning. You play your cards right and you'll never have to worry about money again. Oh, I knew it.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Hello. Whenever there's a pretty woman around, er  This is my nephew, Ted Sheldon, Miss Mitchell.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Thank you very much for everything.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: And, Miss MitchellI think from now on you'd better work directly with me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Better let me talk to him.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: All right, but present it to him as a great cause for the common man.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, somebody else sitting there?

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: No, no, nothat's your seat.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh! Oh, it's beautiful, D. B. WellI don't quite know what to say . . .

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Well, don't say anything at all. Just sit down.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Go ahead, open it, open it.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Tomorrow night, before a crowd of fifteen thousand people, and talking over a nation-wide radio hook-up, John Doe will announce the formation of a third party.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A third party?

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Yes. The John Doe Party.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Devoted entirely to the interests of all the John Does all over the country. Which practically means, ninety per cent of the voters. He will also announce the third party's candidate for the presidency. A man whom he, personally, recommends. A great humanitarian; the best friend the John Does have.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Mr. D. B. Norton!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John! I'm so glad to see you. II was terribly worried.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Hello there. Well, well! If it isn't the man about town!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: All set, Ann?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Huh? Oh, yes. Let's go.  Now, let's see. We want some action in these pictures.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, no, no. This man's going to jump off a roof.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Here. Wait a minute. Let me comb your hair. Sit down. There. That's better.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Stick a fork through me! I'm done. I'll never get this speech right.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, yes you will, Ann dear . . . you're very clever.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, I know. What are you looking for?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Your purse. I need ten dollars.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What for? I gave you fifty just the other day.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, I know, dear, but Mrs. Burke had her baby yesterday. Nine pounds! And there wasn't a thing in the houseand then this morning the Community Chest lady came around and

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And the fifty's all gone, huh? Who's the ten for?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: The Websters.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: The Websters!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You remember those lovely people your father used to take care of? I thought I'd buy them some groceries. Oh, Ann, dear, it's a shame, those poor

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're marvelous, Ma. You're just like Father used to be. Do you realize a couple of weeks ago we didn't have enough to eat ourselves?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, yes, I know, dear, but these people are in such need and we have plenty now.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If you're thinking of that thousand dollars, forget it. It's practically gone. We owed everybody in town. Now, you've just gotta stop giving all your money away.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Ma. Oh, don't pay any attention to me. I guess I'm just upset about all this. Gee whiz, here I am with a great opportunity to get somewhere, to give us security for once in our lives, and I'm stuck. If I could put this over, your Mrs. Burke can have six babies!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Do you mean the speech you're writing?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, I don't know. I simply can't get it to jell!  I created somebody who's gonna give up his life for a principle, hundreds of thousands of people are gonna listen to him over the radio and, unless he says something that's, well, that's sensational, it's just no good!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, honey, of course I don't know what kind of a speech you're trying to write, but judging from the samples I've read, I don't think anybody'll listen.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Darling, there are so many complaining political speeches. People are tired of hearing nothing but doom and despair on the radio. If you're going to have him say anything, why don't you let him say something simple and real, something with hope in it? If your father were alive, he'd know what to say.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, yes, Father certainly would.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Wait a minute . . .

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: That's your father's diary, Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Father's . . . I never knew he had a diary.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: There's enough in it for a hundred speeches, things people ought to hear nowadays. You be careful of it, won't you dear?  It's always helped keep your father alive for me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You bet I will, Ma.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yeh, D. B. Oh, just cleaning out the dead-wood. Okay.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Look, Mr. Connell . . . I just can't afford to be without work right now, not even for a day. I've got a mother and two kid sisters to . . .

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'll tell you what I'll do. I get thirty dollars a week. I'll take twenty-five, twenty if necessary. I'll do anything you say.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: It isn't the money. We're after circulation. What we need is fireworks. People who can hit with sledge hammersstart arguments.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, I can do that. I know this town inside out. Oh, give me a chance, please.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: No. I've had the whole army and navy searching for you because that's a game we play here every day.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I remember, distinctly, being fired.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: That's right. But you have a piece of property that still belongs to this newspaper. And I'd like to have it!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: The letter.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What letter?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: The letter from John Doe.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: The whole town's in an uproar. We've got to find him. The letter's our only clue.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: There is no letter.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: We'll get a handwriting expert to  What!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: There is no letter.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Say that again.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: There is no letter. I made it up.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: You made it up.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Uh-huh. You said you wanted fireworks.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, the whole town's curious about John Doe and, boom, just like that you're going to bury him. There's enough circulation in that man to start a shortage in the ink market!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: In what man!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John Doe.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What John Doe?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Our John Doe! The one I made up! Look, genius Now, look. Suppose there was a John Doeand he walked into this office. What would you do? Find him a job and forget about the whole business, I suppose! Not me! I'd have made a deal with him!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: A deal?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Sure!  When you get hold of a stunt that sells papers you don't drop it like a hot potato. Why, this is good for at least a couple of months. You know what I'd do? Between now and let's say, Christmas, when he's gonna jump, I'd run a daily yarn starting with his boyhood, his schooling, his first job!  A wide-eyed youngster facing a chaotic world. The problem of the average man, of all the John Does in the world.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Now, then comes the drama. He meets discouragement. He finds the world has feet of clay. His ideals crumble. So what does he do?  He decides to commit suicide in protest against the state of civilization. He thinks of the river!  But no, no, he has a better idea. The City Hall. Why?  Because he wants to attract attention. He wants to get a few things off his chest, and that's the only way he can get himself heard.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Very pretty. Very pretty, indeed, Miss Mitchell. But would you mind telling me who goes on Christmas Eve?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John Doe.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What John Doe?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: The one we hire for the job, you lunkhead!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Lemme get this through this lame brain of mine. Are you suggesting we go out and hire someone to say he's gonna commit suicide on Christmas Eve? Is that it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, you're catching on.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Who, for instance?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Anybody! Er, erBeany'll do!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're supposed to be a smart guy! If it was raining hundred dollar bills, you'd be out looking for a dime you lost some place.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Holy smokes! Wasting my time listening to this mad woman.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That's fine! That's fine!  Now fall right into their laps. Go ahead. Say John Doe walked in and called the whole thing off. You know what that's going to sound like on top of this!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: That's all, Ned. Thank you.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Okay, sister, you get your job back.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Plus a bonus.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What bonus?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: I can read. I can read!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: So you think this is worth a thousand dollars, do you?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, the Chronicle would consider it dirt cheap.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Packs everything, including a gun.  Okay, sister, you've got yourself a deal. Now let's take a look at the candidates. The one we pick has gotta be the typical average man. Typical American that can keep his mouth shut.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Looks all right

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He's perfect! A baseball player. What could be more American!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: I wish he had a family, though.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That's our man. He's made to order.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: I don't know. He don't seem like a guy that'd fall into line.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: When you're desperate for money, you do a lot of things, Mr. Connell. He's our man, I tell you.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Hurry up, Pop.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Right here. Sit down.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: All right, boys, here he is.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, no, no! You can't take pictures of him like thateating a sandwichand with a beard!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: But, he's gonna jump off a building!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, but not because he's out of a job. That's not news! This man's going to jump as a matter of principle.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Well, maybe you're right.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: We'll clean him up and put him in a hotel roomunder bodyguards. We'll make a mystery out of him.  Did you speak to Mr. Norton?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Thinks it's terrific. Says for us to go the limit. Wants us to build a bonfire under every big shot in the state.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, swell! Is that the contract?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yes.  What's he doing here?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Friend of his. They play duets together.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Duets? But can we trust him?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Well, okay. But we don't want more than a couple o' hundred people in on this thing. Now the first thing I want is an exact copy of the John Doe letter in your own handwriting.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I got it all ready. Here.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Well, that's fine. Now I want you to sign this agreement. It gives us an exclusive story under your name day by day from now until Christmas. On December twenty-sixth, you get one railroad ticket out of town, and the Bulletin agrees to pay to have your arm fixed. That's what you want, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Okay, fellows.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Take it easy, John Doe.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: And you! Start pounding that typewriter. Oh, boy! This is terrific!  No responsibilities on our part. Just statements from John Doe and we can blast our heads off.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Before you pop too many buttons, don't forget to make out that check for a thousand.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Awwwww!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yeah, but it's got everybody sore. Ads are being pulledthe Governor's starting a libel suitwhat's more, they all know John Doe's a phoneyand they insist on seeing him.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, what about it?  Let them see him!  We'll go them one better. They can also hear him.  You own a radio station, Mr. Norton. Why not put him on the air?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Look. We can't let 'em get to this bush-league pitcher and start pumping him. Good night!  No telling what that screwball might do. I walked in yesterdayhere he is, standing on a table with a fishing pole flycasting. Take my advice and get him out of town before this thing explodes in our faces!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If you do, Mr. Norton, you're just as much of a dumb cluck as he is! Excuse me.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: No, you've got yourself a meal ticket and you hate to let go.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Sure, it's a meal ticket for me. I admit it, but it's also a windfall for somebody like Mr. Norton who's trying to crash national politics.  That's what you bought the newspaper for, isn't it? You wanta reach a lotta people, don't you?  Well, put John Doe on the air and you can reach a hundred and fifty million of 'em. He can say anything he wants and they'll listen to him.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What's the idea?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: No, no, no. Now that's too much!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Listen. If that guy lays an egg. I want to get something out of it. I'm getting a Jane Doe ready!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That's fine, honey. Now, get out!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Now listen, Annhe can't possibly get in without our seeing him. I'm watching the side door and the Colonel's out front, so stop worrying.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How many is that, six? Pretty hungry, weren't you?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Say, all this John Doe business is batty, if yuh ask me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, nobody asked yuh.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Trying to improve the world by jumping off buildings. You couldn't improve the world if the building jumped on you!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, stop worrying. He's all right.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: That's

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Colonel!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: You shouldn't have gotten out of bed, Miss.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Has he been here?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Have you seen him?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: I ain't seen him for a week.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Where's Connell?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: He's watching the other door.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh. Gee, you're swell! Oh.
